Portfolio

About

Hello! I’m Erwin Hilton, a software engineer with both a bachelor’s and master’s degree from MIT.

I’m also an aspiring indie game developer, with experience building projects in Unity, Godot, Phaser 3, and Roblox Studio.

I enjoy experimenting with different engines and frameworks, and I’m always looking for new ways to bring ideas to life through code and design.

Outside of development, I’m an avid Argentine tango dancer, a hobbyist potter, and an enthusiastic home cook.

And, unsurprisingly for an indie game developer, I love playing video games whenever I get the chance.

CMS.611 Final Project

This was a final project developed for the class CMS.611, using the theme "Big and Small". I worked with six other people on this project. In order to fit the theme, we decided to create a game in which players would use their phones as controls while a bigger screen showed all the action.

This project involved a lot of networking using Unity3D's Photon API. Other than that the gameplay was that of a standard space shooter game, with progressive waves and a central spinning 'core' serving as a boss.

  • Date: May 2016
  • Service: Game Development

Game Prototype Using Phaser3

Using the Phaser 3 web framework, I built a 2D game prototype that uses the A* pathfinding algorithm as a basic AI for enemies. I built this as a rudimentary prototype for a larger game that I am working on, and the player has a controller that allows them to traverse the level while a pursuer follows the player's avatar'.

Each enemy has a target and a pursuer, so all the characters follow each other in a chain. This prototype also has a circle graphic that fills up the closer a player is to a target and also points in the target's direction. The player can select targets, and 'kill' them for points if the correct target is eliminated.

Pressing tab also brings up a leaderboard, but enemy AI's are not currently programmed to attack or to collect points.

View Project

  • Date: September 2025
  • Service: Game Development

Livable Cities - MIT Game Lab

I worked as a programmer on a team developing a game for the Samuel Tak Lee MIT Real Estate Entrepreneurship Lab. LivableCities (working title) creates a playful environment for students to explore the basics of real estate development. Players must manage capital and debt, and decide both what sorts of buildings to build and where.

Location of each building is key, as a building’s overall value is influenced by its neighbors – but the type of buildings player choose to build affects how quickly they can build up their capital reserves, and how pleased the citizens of their newly built city are with them.

Link to the Project Website
  • Date: May 2016
  • Service: Game Development

Shaky Shack - MIT Shenkar Workshop

This was a game made in a ten week "purposeful games" workshop hosted by the MIT Game Lab and in partnership with the Shenkar College of Engineering. My team consisted of Michal Skurnik as a game and level designer, Micky Hoz as a programmer, Shiri Blumenthal as an artist, and myself as a programmer.

Shaky Shack is a building game set in a dumpyard, where people's unwanted belongings becomes someone else's treasure and home. The game shows the experiences of the dumplings, helpless creatures in the junkyard. During the game the player needs to build a shelter that will help the dumplings survive against multiple disasters.

  • Date: July 2015
  • Service: Game Development
